metadata.title: Effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and micro-structure of concrete with and without fly ash

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and micro-structure of concrete with and without fly ash Tao Meng, Yue Yu, Zhongjia Wang
PII: S1359-8368(17)30302-5 DOI: 10.1016/j.compositesb.2017.02.030 Reference: JCOMB 4917
To appear in: Composites Part B
Received Date: 25 January 2017 Accepted Date: 18 February 2017
Please cite this article as: Meng T, Yu Y, Wang Z, Effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and micro-structure of concrete with and without fly ash, Composites Part B (2017), doi: 10.1016/j.compositesb.2017.02.030.
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

2
Effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and 27
micro-structure of concrete with and without fly ash 28
Tao Meng1,*, Yue Yu2, Zhongjia Wang3 29
30 Abstract: The effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and 31 microstructure of concrete with and without fly ash was studied in this paper. 32 Experimental results showed that nano-CaCO3 slurry was helpful to increase the 33 mechanical strength of concrete with and without fly ash at early ages due to the 34 acceleration of cement hydration from seeding effect and the more compact 35 microstructure of cement paste from nano-filling. However, the efficacy of nano-CaCO3 36 slurry on the concrete without fly ash was quite limited at the late ages just like other 37 nano-materials. This may well affect the application of nano-materials in concrete. On 38 the other hand, nano-CaCO3 slurry was still helpful to enhance the mechanical strength 39 of concrete with fly ash at late ages. Furthermore, the enhancement degree of 40 mechanical strength of concrete with fly ash at 56 days increased with the increasing 41 content of fly ash when 2% fly ash was substituted by nano-CaCO3. The results of X-Ray 42 diffraction analysis and SEM observation indicated that the pozzolanic reaction degree 43 of fly ash could be accelerated by nano-CaCO3 slurry at late ages. Therefore, a feasible 44 technique for the usage of composite nano-materials in concrete may well be provided 45 by using nano-CaCO3 with fly ash due to the acceleration hydration of cement at early 46 ages and that of fly ash at late ages. 47 Author keywords: nano-CaCO3; mechanical properties; microstructure; concrete; fly ash. 48 49 1 Introduction 50
In recent years, concrete has become the most widely used material in civil engineering. 51 However, the limited improvement in mechanical properties and durability of concrete is 52
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
still a severe problem due to the high porosity, weak cohesion and loose microstructure. 53 At the same time, nano-materials have been studied and used more widely and deeply in 54 space navigation, electronic engineering and chemical industry due to their tiny size, 55 huge specific surface area and some special properties. Thus, nano-materials may well 56 be a prospective method to modify the properties of concrete and to achieve a better 57 requirement of construction[1,2]. 58 Nowadays, many valuable researches have been conducted concerning the effect of 59 nano-materials on the mechanical properties and microstructure of cementitious 60 materials. It was said that compressive strength of cement mortar at 3 days increased by 61 35% when 3% content of nano-SiO2 was added into. Moreover, the permeability of 62 concrete also decreased by adding nano-SiO2 due to the nano-filling function which 63 meant nano-materials could improve the density of concrete by blocking the pore and 64 the micro-crack in concrete. Furthermore, nano-SiO2 may possess a high hydrated 65 activity and perform as the nucleus which would be helpful to accelerate the formation 66 of cement hydrates such as CSH gel and Ettringite. Thus, the strength and 67 impermeability of concrete could be improved by nano-SiO2[3-9]. 68 Other nano-materials also showed a magnificent effect on the properties of cementitious 69 materials[10-13]. Results showed that compressive strength of concrete increased by 70 from 15% to 20% and the elasticity modulus of concrete increased by more than 40% 71 when 5% content of cement was substituted by nano-Al2O3[14]. It was implied that 72 nano-filling and the accelerating formation of hydrated products may well be the reason 73 for the enhancement in mechanical properties of concrete which was studied and 74 analyzed by TEM and mechanical test method[15]. The similar results were presented in 75 the research on the effect of nano-ZnO2,nano-Cr2O3 and carbon nano-tube[16-18]. 76 Even if these nano-materials indicated a brilliant influence and a prospective application 77 in concrete research, however it was seldom reported nano-materials were widely used 78 in concrete industry and civil engineering. The main reason may be the high price of 79
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
these nano-materials and the limited achievement at late ages. Therefore, the key point 80 in the application of alternative nano-materials should be the acceptable expense and 81 the better performance in the utilization of concrete. 82 It was found that nano-CaCO3 was widely used in plastic industry as the enhancement 83 addition due to the high efficacy and the cheap price. If nano-CaCO3 has a good effect on 84 the properties of concrete, it will present a real and hopeful prospect in the application 85 of nano-modified concrete. However, nano-CaCO3 may well be difficult to disperse in the 86 cement paste and could be harmful for the hydration of cement especially at the late 87 ages because many kinds of additions such as coupling agent were added in order to 88 obtain the compatible performance between nano-CaCO3 and organic-based materials in 89 the manufacture process of nano-CaCO3 powder[19]. Therefore, it could be unsuitable to 90 use nano-CaCO3 powder directly into concrete[20,21], even if some interesting results 91 about the effect of pure CaCO3 powder on the hydration process of cement were 92 reported[22-26]. 93 This paper aimed at the nano-CaCO3 slurry, which is obtained after carbonation and 94 filtration on the process of manufacture before adding the organic additions to control 95 the shape and growth of crystal and improve the cohesive force between nano-CaCO3 96 and organic matrix, and studied the effect on the mechanical properties and 97 microstructure of concrete with and without fly ash. 98
99
2 Experiment 100
2.1 Materials 101 P.O42.5 cement according to Chinese standard GB 175-2007 produced by Lafarge 102 Cement Company[27], river sand with 2.6 fineness modulus and crushed stone with the 103 31.5mm maximum diameter were used. Fly ash with grade Ⅱ according to Chinese 104
standard GB/T 1596-2005 produced by Changxing Power Plant, naphthalene-based 105 superplasticizer with water reduce ratio of 25% produced by Wulong Company were 106
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
5
provided[28]. Tab. 1 showed the chemical composition and some physical properties of 107 fly ash. Nano-CaCO3 slurry with the solid content of 18.9% was provided by Jiande 108 Tianshi Company. Figs. 1 and 2 showed the X-Ray diffraction curve and SEM image of 109 nano-CaCO3 made by drying nano-CaCO3 slurry at 105℃ for 2 days, respectively. 110
2.2 Experimental Method 111 2.2.1 Compressive strength test 112 Concrete specimens were molded and conserved on the 20℃ condition according to the 113 mix proportion of tab. 2. The total water included the mixing water and the water in 114 nano-CaCO3 slurry. The total water/binder ratio used for all mixtures was 0.45 and the 115 ratio of fine aggregate to total aggregate was 0.42. The amount of nano-CaCO3 and 116 superplasiticizer were 2% and 0.5% by weight of binder respectively, while the 117 replacements of cement by fly ash were 15%, 30% and 45% respectively. The 118 compressive strength tests of concrete were conducted according to Chinese National 119 Standard GB/T 50081-2003[29]. Fig. 3 showed the compressive strength of different 120 concrete specimens at different ages, and figs.4 and 5 indicated the strength ratio 121 between 1 day and 56 days of concrete with fly ash and enhancement degree of 122 strength in different specimens by nano-CaCO3 at 1 day and 56 days, respectively. 123 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction Analysis 124 Concrete specimens were broken and mortar particles were picked and grinded to the 125 residue ratio on the 45 um sieve less than 2% at specific age. The XRD test was done by 126 Kigahu D/Max-3B X-ray Diffraction Instrument. Tab. 3 showed the diffraction intensity 127 of Ca(OH)2 and C3S in different specimens at different ages. Figs. 6 and 7 indicated the 128 reduction value in diffraction intensity of C3S from 1 day to 3 days in different 129 specimens and average reduction value in diffraction intensity of CH from 7 days to 28 130 days in different specimens, respectively. 131 2.2.3 Scanning Electron Microscope 132 The mortar specimens for SEM were molded and conserved on the 20℃ condition, 133
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
6
before they were broken into small fragments and the hydration was stopped by pure 134 alcohol at specific age. Those small fragments were sprayed with gold for 60s in SBC-12 135 Small Particles Sputtering Apparatus to make specimens conductive. Microscopic 136 structure of specimens under different magnifications was observed with HITACHI 137 S-570. Fig. 8 and Fig.9 showed the SEM images of different concrete at 1 day, while Fig. 138 10 and Fig.11 showed the SEM images of fly ash concrete with and without nano-CaCO3 139 slurry at 28 days. 140 141 3 Analysis and Discussion 142
Tab.1 implied the main minerals of fly ash were SiO2 and Al2O3 and fig. 1 indicated that 143 the crystallinic degree of nano-CaCO3 slurry was clear after drying while fig. 2 indicated 144 that the size of crystal was approximately from 60nm to 80nm. 145 Tab.2 showed the mix proportion of fly ash concrete with and without nano-CaCO3 146 slurry. The contents of fly ash were 15%, 30% and 45% respectively. Moreover, 147 specimen N2F13, N2F28 and N2F43 meant the total content of fly ash was 15%, 30% 148 and 45% respectively, and 2% fly ash was substituted by nano-CaCO3. 149 From the results of compressive strength of different concrete specimens which was 150 shown in fig. 3, it could be concluded that the compressive strength of concrete with fly 151 ash decreased with the increasing content of fly ash at early ages while the compressive 152 strength in concrete with fly ash at late ages was a slight higher than or close to that in 153 the normal concrete. 154 The strength ratio (f1/f56) of concrete specimens with fly ash between 1 day and 56 155 days was calculated and shown in fig.4. It could be found that f1/f56 of specimens 156 decreased with the increasing content of fly ash due to the reduction in cement content 157 and the hydration of fly ash at late ages. Compared to the specimens without 158 nano-CaCO3, f1/f56 of specimens with nano-CaCO3 increased significantly. This may well 159 be caused by the enhancement in compressive strength at 1 day due to seeding effect 160
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
7
and nano-filling of nano-CaCO3. Therefore, it could be concluded that nano-CaCO3 slurry 161 was much helpful to improve the strength of concrete at early ages. 162 At the same time, in order to analysis the influence of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the 163 hydration of fly ash, the enhancement degree in compressive strength by nano-CaCO3 at 164 different ages and different content of fly ash was calculated and was shown in fig.5. It 165 seemed that the enhancement degree in compressive strength was very high and 166 almost the same at 1 day but increased with the increasing content of fly ash at 56 days. 167 In this experiment, when the total content of fly ash was 15%, 30% and 45% 168 respectively, the enhancement degree of compressive strength at 56 days was -8.1%, 169 -4.7% and 4.9% respectively when 2% fly ash was substituted by nano-CaCO3. This 170 meant nano-CaCO3 may accelerate the hydration of fly ash especially at late ages. A 171 similar result was obtained in the experiment of cement mortar with compound slag 172 powder and calcium carbonate[23]. Therefore, the hydration of fly ash could well be 173 accelerated by nano-CaCO3 slurry, which seemed to be very useful and important for 174 concrete with a large amount of fly ash. 175 Tab. 3 showed the intensity of diffraction peak in different specimens at different ages. 176 The diffraction intensity of C3S in specimen J decreased and that of CH in specimen J 177 increased along with the increasing hydration ages. Meanwhile, the diffraction intensity 178 of CH at 28 days presented a bit reduction compared to that at 7 days because the 179 pozzolanic reaction of potential cementitious materials in the cement may cause the 180 consumption of CH. The change in diffraction intensity of specimens with fly ash at 181 different ages was similar as that of specimen J even if the diffraction intensity of 182 specimen F45 was lower than that of other specimens due to the low content of cement. 183 However, the diffraction intensity in specimens with fly ash and nano-CaCO3 was 184 different. Firstly, the diffraction intensity of C3S in specimens with nano-CaCO3 implied 185 a quicker consumption speed than that without nano-CaCO3 due to the accelerated 186 hydration of cement. Secondly, while the diffraction intensity of CH in specimens with 187
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
8
nano-CaCO3 decreased with the increasing content of fly ash, the diffraction intensity of 188 CH at 1 day was obviously higher than that of specimen without nano-CaCO3 due to the 189 accelerated hydration of cement. However, diffraction intensity of CH in specimens with 190 nano-CaCO3 increased slower than that in specimens without nano-CaCO3 due to the 191 hydration of nano-CaCO3 and the accelerated hydration of fly ash by nano-CaCO3. Since 192 the content of nano-CaCO3 was only 2% by weight of the cement, the second one should 193 be the main reason. Finally, an obvious difference in diffraction intensity of CH between 194 7 days and 28 days could be found in the specimens with nano-CaCO3. 195 Therefore, in order to analysis the change in diffraction intensity of different specimens 196 more clearly, the reduction value of diffraction intensity of C3S from 1 day to 3 days in 197 different specimens and the average reduction value of diffraction intensity of CH from 198 7 days to 28 days in different specimens were calculated and was shown in figs.6 and 7, 199 respectively. 200 It could be found from fig.6 that the diffraction intensity of C3S decreased with the 201 increasing hydration age especially at the early ages. Furthermore, nano-CaCO3 showed 202 an obvious efficacy on the reduction value of its diffraction intensity, that is to say, 203 nano-CaCO3 could significantly accelerate the hydration of C3S due to the seeding effect. 204 As for the hydration at late ages, the content of CH may well be decreased because of 205 the hydration of fly ash. Therefore, the change of diffraction intensity of CH could 206 indicate the hydration degree of fly ash. Because the two main specific apex of CH were 207 situated at 2Ɵ of 18o and 34.1o due to the diffraction of crystal planes (001) and (101) 208 respectively, the average reduction values of diffraction intensity in different specimens 209 between 7 days and 56 days were calculated in order to present the change in hydration 210 degree of fly ash. Fig. 7 implied nano-CaCO3 may probably increase the hydration 211 degree of fly ash significantly, particularly in the specimen with high content of fly ash. 212 This was helpful to modify the properties of concrete with high content of fly ash. 213
Fig. 8 showed the micro-morphology image of specimen F15 at 1 day. It seemed that 214
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
9
many hydrates could be formed on the surface of fly ash particles. Due to the high 215 alkalinity of hydration products, the tight glass-shell of fly ash particles would be 216 dissolved and hydrated at late ages, which was useful for the enhancement of strength 217 and the improvement of density in concrete. Fig.9 presented a different image of 218 concrete with nano-CaCO3 at 1 day. Many fibrous hydrates were formed and it seemed 219 that a kind of hydrates network was weaved by these hydrates branches due to the 220 accelerated hydration of cement and fly ash by nano-CaCO3. Furthermore, some small 221 piles which may be made up of nano-CaCO3, hydrates and fly ash could be found in the 222 network. This also could prove nano-CaCO3 was useful to accelerate the hydration of 223 cement due to the seeding effect and the hydration of nano-CaCO3[23]. An increased 224 early strength has been tested in the concrete with slag powder and calcium carbonate 225 and fly ash with nano-TiO2 and nanographite[30-32]. Thus, it could well be very helpful 226 to improve the hydration degree and compressive strength of concrete at early 227 hydration age. 228 Figs. 8 and 10 showed the SEM images of fly ash particles in specimen F15 at 1 day and 229 28 days, respectively. Many hydrated products could be found on the surface of fly ash 230 in specimen F15. This may be very helpful for the accelerated hydration of fly ash and 231 the improvement of concrete strength. Even if the surface of fly ash was still very clear 232 at 1 day, but it was scraggy and part of glass-shell disappeared at 28 days because of the 233 pozzalanic reaction of fly ash. Meanwhile, most of fly ash particles seemed have been 234 preserved well while the hydrated products adhered on the surface of fly ash particles 235 and reacted with fly ash. Fig. 11 showed the appearance of fly ash particles in specimen 236 N2F13 which was the similar size with those particles from fig.10. The inner frame of 237 fly ash particle collapsed and some hydrated products grown up from the micro-crack 238 in the particle. After considering with the results of compressive strength and X-ray 239 diffraction, it could be concluded that nano-CaCO3 was helpful to accelerate the 240 hydration of fly ash especially at the evening ages. 241
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
10
242 Conclusions 243
The effect of nano-CaCO3 slurry on the mechanical properties and microstructure of 244 concrete with and without fly ash was studied in this paper. 245 Results showed the crystallinic degree of nano-CaCO3 slurry was clear and the size of 246 nano-CaCO3 crystal varied from 60nm to 80nm. When nano-CaCO3 slurry was added 247 into the concrete, the compressive strength of concrete with and without fly ash all 248 could be improved significantly at the early ages because the hydration of cement may 249 be accelerated by nano-filling and seeding effect of nano-CaCO3. Compare to the blank 250 concrete specimen without nano-CaCO3, strength ratio f1/f56 of specimens increased 251 obviously due to the obvious enhancement of strength at 1 day when 2% binder was 252 replaced by nano-CaCO3. Furthermore, when the total content of fly ash was 15%, 30% 253 and 45% respectively, the enhancement degree of compressive strength at 56 days was 254 -8.1%, -4.7% and 4.9% respectively when 2% fly ash was substituted by nano-CaCO3. 255 This meant the hydration of fly ash at late ages could be accelerated by nano-CaCO3. 256 Moreover, the X-Ray diffraction analysis and SEM observations of those specimens with 257 and without nano-CaCO3 at different ages were conducted and the results also indicated 258 that nano-CaCO3 was helpful for the hydration of fly ash. 259 It could be concluded that nano-CaCO3 slurry was helpful to modify the strength and 260 microstructure of concrete with fly ash because it may well accelerate both the 261 hydration of cement at early ages and the hydration of fly ash at late ages. 262 263 Acknowledgement 264
The authors sincerely thank for the financial support of the major Scientific and 265 Technological Project in Zhejiang Province(No. 2005C11040) and the experimental 266 assistance from Jiande Tianshi Company, Zhejiang. 267 268

However, nano-CaCO3 may well be difficult to disperse in the 86 cement paste and could be harmful for the hydration of cement especially at the late 87 ages because many kinds of additions such as coupling agent were added in order to 88 obtain the compatible performance between nano-CaCO3 and organic-based materials in 89 the manufacture process of nano-CaCO3 powder[19].
